p: Many plants have long been known to be a significant source of effective antidiabetic drugs in developing countries, especially to reduce the cost of conventional treatments [ 217]. Phytoconstituents, such as terpenoids, flavonoids, alkaloids, carotenoids, saponins, glycosides, which have antidiabetic effects, are now used to treat diseases such as diabetes [ 219, 222]. Indeed, the number of people living with diabetes is rising, stoking concerns among medical professionals and the public. Despite the availability of antidiabetic medications in the market, medicinal plants are also effective [ 217]. The Araucaria, Cedrus, Juniperus, Pinus, Thuja, and Taxus genera have all been studied for their antidiabetic, antihyperglycemic, and hypoglycemic properties, as well as their ability to inhibit α-amylase and α-glucosidase and shown in Table 6.
